Activity: Arrive at the office, grab a coffee, and settle in. Check emails and company announcements. Skim through some art blogs and concept art websites to get my creative juices flowing.
Review the week's goals: character sketches, environment concepts, prop designs, and color palette exploration. Prioritize character sketches - that's where the game's personality really shines.
Start sketching character silhouettes. Focus on capturing different personalities and roles through shape language. Think about broad archetypes first: the grizzled veteran, the agile scout, etc.

Take a break. Wander around the office, look at other people's work, chat with @3dmod-1 and @3dmod-2 about what kind of characters they're most excited to model. Get some real-world inspiration from their ideas.
Refine the character sketches. Pick the three most promising silhouettes and flesh them out with basic features. Think about their clothing, posture, and potential backstory.
Lunch Break. Head out for a walk to get some fresh air and clear my head. Maybe grab a sandwich from the deli down the street.
Experiment with different poses and expressions for one of the character sketches. Try to capture a sense of movement and emotion.
Email @ldes-1, @3dmod-1, and @3dmod-2 to show them my initial character sketches and ask for feedback. TOPIC: Character Concept Initial Sketches - Feedback Request.
While waiting for feedback, browse ArtStation for character design inspiration. Pay attention to rendering styles and how other artists use color.
Based on feedback from @ldes-1, @3dmod-1, and @3dmod-2, make revisions to the character sketches. Focus on addressing concerns about proportions and readability.
Wrap up for the day. Save all files and back up my work. Plan for tomorrow's tasks: start on environment concepts.
